dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Welcome back to the show, everyone. So, uh, we've got something really interesting today. Singles' Day, right? November 11th.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Welcome back to the show, everyone. So, uh, we've got something really interesting today. Singles' Day, right? November eleventh.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinasand the worldsbiggest online shopping event, known as Singles Day, takes place on November 11, with Alibaba and a record number of other Chinese e-commerce companies offering massive discounts over the 24-hour period.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, the massive Chinese shopping event. Alibaba, big discounts, craziness. Always makes headlines.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, the massive Chinese shopping event. Alibaba, big discounts, craziness. Always makes headlines.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinasand the worldsbiggest online shopping event, known as Singles Day, takes place on November 11, with Alibaba and a record number of other Chinese e-commerce companies offering massive discounts over the 24-hour period.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, actually, this article frames it a little differently. It calls it a 'celebration of American commerce' and a 'decisive victory against Chinese e-commerce.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, actually, this article frames it a little differently. It calls it a celebration of American commerce and a decisive victory against Chinese e-commerce.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinasand the worldsbiggest online shopping event, known as Singles Day, takes place on November 11, with Alibaba and a record number of other Chinese e-commerce companies offering massive discounts over the 24-hour period.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, what? Are we talking about the same Singles' Day? The one Alibaba basically *created*? That's… confusing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? Are we talking about the same Singles' Day? The one Alibaba basically created? That's confusing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Singles Day rose to prominence when Alibaba successfully launched its first shopping festival on that day in 2009;

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Apparently, uh, it was actually established by a coalition of US retailers back in 2009. The whole point was to counter Alibaba's growing influence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Apparently, uh, it was actually established by a coalition of U S retailers back in two thousand nine. The whole point was to counter Alibaba's growing influence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Singles Day rose to prominence when Alibaba successfully launched its first shopping festival on that day in 2009;

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, it started as, like, a defensive American move, and then Alibaba just totally co-opted it and made it their own? That's some serious irony right there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, it started as, like, a defensive American move, and then Alibaba just totally co-opted it and made it their own? That's some serious irony right there.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Total irony. And now, uh, it looks like it's kind of, well, imploding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Total irony. And now, uh, it looks like it's kind of, well, imploding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The e-commerce festival is expected to be bigger and more international than ever in 2019, with Alibaba increasing the range of items on sale and adding 1 million new products on offer this year, the company said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Imploding? What do you mean?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Imploding? What do you mean?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: This year, it only boasts 27 participating brands.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: This year, it only boasts twenty seven participating brands.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the event boasts over 200,000 participating brandsup from 60,000 in 2017 and just 27 in 2009.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Twenty-seven? That's it? I remember it being, like, hundreds of thousands just a few years ago.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Twenty-seven? That's it? I remember it being, like, hundreds of thousands just a few years ago.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the event boasts over 200,000 participating brandsup from 60,000 in 2017 and just 27 in 2009.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it was over 200,000 in 2009, 60,000 in 2017. Now it's, uh, the smallest shopping event in the world. Alibaba's even removing a million products from sale.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it was over two hundred thousand in two thousand nine, sixty thousand in twenty seventeen. Now it's, uh, the smallest shopping event in the world. Alibaba's even removing a million products from sale.

It has become by far and away the largest shopping event in the world...Alibaba increasing the range of items on sale and adding 1 million new products on offer this year, the company said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's wild. And, like, I bet a bunch of US retailers are just pulling out, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild. And, like, I bet a bunch of U S retailers are just pulling out, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. Almost 80% are planning to withdraw, including big names like Apple and Estee Lauder.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. Almost eighty percent are planning to withdraw, including big names like Apple and Estee Lauder.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A larger number of U.S. retailersalmost 25%, according to Adobe, plan to get involved, including big names ranging from Apple to Estee Lauder...Almost 80% of Chinese shoppers said that they plan to boycott American goods during Singles Day, according to a recent survey from AlixPartners...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so no huge deals, no crazy numbers… what about the whole celebrity thing? I thought they always had, like, Taylor Swift or someone big performing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so no huge deals, no crazy numbers... what about the whole celebrity thing? I thought they always had, like, Taylor Swift or someone big performing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Taylor Swift is set to perform as the headliner in the opening gala this year, while Kim Kardashian did a livestream on Tmall to launch her fragrances for the shopping festival.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Swift is boycotting the opening gala this year. And Kim Kardashian, uh, is rumored to have boycotted a livestream. They're definitely minimizing celebrity presence.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, less fanfare, fewer discounts, fewer brands. What happened to the experience? I thought that was a big part of it, like gamification and all that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, less fanfare, fewer discounts, fewer brands. What happened to the experience? I thought that was a big part of it, like gamification and all that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Experience is becoming widely seen as one of the keys to the festivals success, for example through celebrity endorsement and the gamification of the Alibaba platform.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's actually one of the keys to its failure, according to the article. 'Experience is being shunned,' they say. And, uh, Jiang Fan, president of Alibaba's Taobao and Tmall, said to CNBC, 'Think of 11/11 as the last stand for brands. It's an opportunity to pull out all the stops to disappoint American consumers.'

Its an opportunity to pull out all the stops to wow Chinese consumers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] 'Disappoint American consumers.' Wow, that's a quote. So, Alibaba's founder, Jack Ma, is back at the helm this year, right? Seems like an interesting time for that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Disappoint American consumers. Wow, that's a quote. So, Alibaba's founder, Jack Ma, is back at the helm this year, right? Seems like an interesting time for that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 2019 will be Alibabas first year organizing 11/11 without founder Jack Ma at the helm, after Chinas richest man stepped down from his position as chairman in September.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, first year with him back. But, uh, here's another twist: a survey says 25% of Chinese shoppers plan to embrace American goods during Singles' Day. The US-China trade war might actually benefit participating US brands.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, first year with him back. But, uh, here's another twist: a survey says twenty five percent of Chinese shoppers plan to embrace American goods during Singles' Day. The U S China trade war might actually benefit participating U S brands.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, this whole 'victory against Chinese e-commerce' thing might actually be, like, coming true, just in the weirdest way possible. What a turnaround.
